clinical_study.brief_title: ST- Depression on Electrocardiogram During Caesarean Section in Regional Anaesthesia in Women With Preeclampsia
clinical_study.official_title: Randomised Study on Cardiac Effects of Oxytocin During Caesarean Section in Preeclamptic Women

brief_summary.textblock: The investigators examined whether there was a difference in the occurrence of ST depressions after injection of five or ten units of oxytocin, in preeclamptic patients delivered by caesarean section (CS) under regional anesthesia.

detailed_description.textblock:
ST depression on electrocardiograms has been reported in healthy women undergoing cesarean section in regional anesthesia. The investigators examined whether there was a difference in the occurrence of electrocardiogram changes suggestive of myocardial ischemia (ST depressions) in preeclamptic patients randomized to five or ten units of oxytocin during cesarean section with regional anesthesia.
In a double-blind randomized controlled study preeclamptic patients undergoing cesarean section under spinal anesthesia were randomized to 5 or 10 units of oxytocin, given as an intravenous bolus. A Holter monitor was used to record electrocardiograms. Non-invasive blood pressure and heart rate were monitored.

primary_outcome.measure: Depression of the ST segment on electrocardiograms
primary_outcome.time_frame: From start of caesarean section until 20 minutes after delivery

secondary_outcome.measure: Mean arterial pressure and heart rate.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From start of caesarean section until 20 minutes after delivery

intervention.description: Intravenous bolus dose given during 1 minute after clamping of the umbilical cord
